name: CIP-04
language: 48K Spectrum BASIC and 128K Spectrum ZX+3 BASIC  with +3 DOS (probably)
keyboard: Full-stroke keyboard, QWERTY, 40 keys (same as CIP-64)
cpu: MMN-80. East European clone of the Z80-A
sound: AY-3-8912 3 voice + white noise sound generator
ports: TV/RF, Composite video, tape recorder, serial and parallel ports, expansion bus connector, DC in, joystick
description:
The CIP-04 seems to be a clone of the Sinclair Spectrum +3.

However, despite similar or higher technical features (256 KB of RAM, 64 KB of ROM, built-in Floppy Disk Drives), the system was not compatible with all Spectrums because of its 3.5" FDD instead of the 3" Spectrum model (though the 3.5" FDD was a better choice).

The 64 KB of ROM probably hold the 48K Spectrum BASIC, 128K Spectrum ZX+3 BASIC and CP/M operating system

Additional information from Grecu Cristi:
The CIP-04 is very close to Sinclair ZX Spectrum +3, probably the only +3 clone from Romania. It's ROM software is almost identical; but at power-on the message is "(c)" instead "(c) Amstrad...".
The menu is identical, with loader, 128 BASIC, Calculator and 48K basic. It has the AY-3-8912 sound chip, the video connector is also used for sound output.
The disk is managed through +3DOS, a method cloned from Amstrad's +3. The disk is 3,5", single sided, double density, 40 tracks. It's somekind silly to use 720K floppies, and use only 1/4 of its capacity! But I think this is also cloned from +3. The controller chip is a CM609P, a russian clone of the 8272. Being a total clone, I bet it can also run CP/M.
It has a one-direction parallel port, providing 8 data lines, STROBE and ACK. No PIO was used, it is probably controlled by soft. It also has a serial connector, but no UART is used. Also probably driven by software. Transistors were used instead of the classic MC-1488. Very unprofessional!
Joystick connector: Two Sinclair joystics. Uses keys 1..0.
Memory: Although near the keyboard is said BIG, "256 kbytes", from the 128K basic interpretor we may access only 128 KB. The memory consists of eight K565RU7G, 256 Kbits each. So indeed, it has 256  Kbytes!
Two M27C256B (64 KB) hold the ROM software, just like the +3. I also saw about 5 more ROMs, MN74L287, 256*4 bits each. I don't know what are those good for.
Something stupid: The expansion bus is very close to the power supply jack, so there is no space to plug in a peripheral. Not even the original Electronica's joystick interface.
Power supply issues: It needs 5V, plus on the central pin. Careful: Like all the CIPs, it hasn't internal stabiliser. +12V is provided inside for the serial interface and other chips.

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR CONNECTORS</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> Joyctick DB9 connector<br> <b>(2)</b> Power supply jack plug. An external PSU supply the power<br> <b>(3)</b> Expansion/Z80 bus connector<br> <b>(4)</b> Parallel interface DB 25 connector<br> <b>(5)</b> Serial port DIN plug<br> <b>(6)</b> Tape recorder DIN plug<br> <b>(7)</b> Composite video DIN plug<br> <b>(8)</b> TV modulator output<br> <b>(9)</b> Reset switch</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE CIP</strong></font><br><blockquote>Like the CIP-64, this version doesn't use any ULA custom chip, but only standard East European chips.<br><br> <b>(1)</b> RF/TV aerial modulator<br> <b>(2)</b> Composite video DIN plug<br> <b>(3)</b> Tape recorder DIN plug<br> <b>(4)</b> Serial port DIN plug<br> <b>(5)</b> Parallel port DB25 connector <br> <b>(6)</b> FDD controller chip<br> <b>(7)</b> MMN-80 processor (Z80-A clone)<br> <b>(8)</b> Expansion/Z80 Bus connector<br> <b>(9)</b> 2 x 27C256 ROM chips (32 KB x 2)<br> <b>(10)</b> Joystick DB9 connector<br> <b>(11)</b> 8 East European memory chips holding 256 KB of RAM</blockquote>

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2 (SEPT. 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> THE FIRST M20 VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>This Olivetti ancestor, also called M20, was born in 1920...<br> To note the superb design all the young italian secretaries were in love of! <p class="petitgris">Thanks to Karl-Heinz  -  www.sharpmz.org</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> As the American magazine 'Byte' commented, "for some time to come the 1040STF will be the clear leader in price/performance." </font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first sentence of this advert is:<br> <i>The new Commodore 64  is the most powerful personal computer available to the businessman.</i><br> Which wasn't totally true, even totally false.<br><br> The picture is also totally unrealistic. Each detail sounds false.<br> The C64 never was a business system, but a perfect home computer.  </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (FEB. 1980) </strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Wilson for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juan Antonio Maestre for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT#1 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Computing: an era comes to the end" <br><br> "The Sirius era begins"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JACQUARD BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DIAGRAMS</strong></font><br><blockquote>PMI-80 diagram located in the case cover.<br> If you are interested in more diagrams of the PMI-80, dowload this zipped <a href="http://www.old-computers.com/Museum/downloads/Tesla_PMI80_Diagrams.zip">file</a> holding three diagrams of the whole system.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SOFTCARD COPY</strong></font><br><blockquote>An advert for one of the numerous copies of the Microsoft SotfCard. Initially, they were manufactured in the United States then in Asia.   </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Imagine the new world that would unfold before you if you had a powerful , portable, completely integrated computer system at your personal disposal. And at an affordable price. That's exactly what Hewlett-Packard has just created.<br> At the lab, on your desk or in your study this 20-pound, self-contained  system provides professional computing power when and where you need it. That means no more waiting for data to be remotely processed and returned.</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ENGLISH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>English advert for the 86A model.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Tony Mattson for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1982 HEATHKIT CENTERS</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Canon AS-100. Programmed to succeed."</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ACE 1000 ADVERT(1982) #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE #4</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LUCAS LOGIC BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://wotsit.thingy.com/haj/">Howard Jones</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LEAFLET (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The TO7 from Thomson has everything needed to fill the empty cells"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (NOV. 1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is the only SILEX advert known so far... <br><br> It says : "Silex, a stone in our competitors garden." <br><br> Silex means flint in french, a stone mainly used in prehistoric times as tools and weapons. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RADIOLA ADVERT. 2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROTOTYPE SOFTWARE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This picture from an early advert published in january 1983 is very interesting (the TO-7 was just released then). The text below it said "Hours of entertainment...". But when you look more carefully at the software boxes you realise that they are fake! Only the two extreme boxes are real, but still shows the same game title "3-D TIC-TAC TOE"! So there is only one game presented here! The photograph was surely taken at an early development stage... <br><br> Even the name of the computer written on top of the boxes: "TOM 7" (Tele Ordinateur Multimedia?) seems to be an early name for the TO-7... <br><br> Hours of entertainment they said...</blockquote>

builtInGames: 48K Spectrum BASIC and 128K Spectrum ZX+3 BASIC  with +3 DOS (probably)
peripherals: All Sinclair/Spectrum extensions using the expansion bus connector
